Siresp, which is based in Cagliari, Sardinia, had been due to perform a series of tests in the lead up to the floods, but had only managed to carry out a third of the required tests. The network had also failed to update its map of the area with a number of buildings that had been built after the last official survey.

Neill has received disability support, but has been left with a substantial debt of more than £100,000.
A friend set up a JustGiving page to help raise money to pay for Neill's debt. The page has now raised more than £80,000.
It is not yet clear whether the money will cover the full amount. Neill has thanked everyone who has donated.
We are sorry to hear about Neill’s experience, and wish him well for the future.

Complaints about data collection by GCHQ, MI5 and MI6 were put forward by campaign group Privacy International. The ruling said some of the activities carried out by the UK security services were “wholly or largely indiscriminate” and not subject to adequate safeguards.
But it also said that in many cases, the information is collected “to protect the national security of the United Kingdom, its citizens, and its residents, and there is a pressing need to be able to obtain, use, and retain communications data in order to carry out its legitimate aim”.
It added that the UK security services “operate within a clear legal and policy framework, which includes rigorous oversight, including by the Investigatory Powers Tribunal”.

The event, entitled Shifting the Curve - Sharing the Challenge, is aimed at addressing the relatively static rates of breastfeeding in Scotland over the last decade. Figures show 48.4% of babies were breastfed at around ten days old in 2013/14, compared with 44.4% in 2004/05. The data shows a trend towards babies being fed both breast and formula milk, as well as a decline in breastfeeding by the six to eight week stage. Experts in the field will come together to share the latest evidence on the benefits of breastfeeding, review what is working well and identify ways to drive up rates. A key focus will be on increasing rates of breastfeeding in the most deprived areas in order to help reduce health inequalities. Mothers in the wealthiest areas are nearly three times as likely to exclusively breastfeed at six to eight weeks, compared with those in the most deprived areas.

The event, entitled Shifting the Curve - Sharing the Challenge, is aimed at addressing the relatively static rates of breastfeeding in Scotland over the last decade.
The event will take place on Thursday 29 November 2018 at the National Museum of Scotland in Edinburgh. It will be chaired by Dr Andrew Fraser, Senior Lecturer in Public Health at the University of Glasgow.
The event will explore the latest evidence on how to support women to breastfeed, the barriers to breastfeeding and how to tackle these and the importance of breastfeeding for the health and wellbeing of women, babies and families.
The event will also hear from breastfeeding experts from around the world, including Professor Alison Stuebe from the USA and Professor Judy Wright from Australia.
The event is free to attend, however, places are limited. If you would like to attend please register online here.

Pensions expert John Ralfe has worked with the scheme for the last 10 years, and is currently advising the trustees on their strategy for the coming years. John talks to us about the role of the trustees and the issues they face.
How would you describe your role as a pensions trustee?
I am a non-executive director and independent trustee of the Vauxhall Pension Trust. I joined the scheme in 2005 and was chairman of the trustees until 2010.
What is the role of a trustee?
The main role of a trustee is to make sure that the benefits promised to the pensioners are delivered. Trustees are the guardians of the fund and are the ultimate decision-makers. They are responsible for the investment of the assets and the payment of benefits. They must ensure that the pension scheme is run in the best interests of the members and beneficiaries of the fund.
